fr:title.text: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A functor D\xrightarrow {G} C is a right adjoint if and only if, for each c\in C, the comma category c\downarrow G has an initial object. Dually, C\xrightarrow {F} D is a left adjoint if and only if, for each d\in D, the comma category F\downarrow d has a terminal object. (Here, c is the constant functor at c.)
In the forwards direction, we obtain the result since adjoint assignments are universal and universal elements are initial in exactly the specified category of elements.

In the backwards direction, let c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} Gd_0 be initial in c\downarrow G; let Fc = d_0. Initiality of \eta _c means that, for any map c\to Gd, there is a unique map Fc\to d in D making the triangle commute. In other words, \eta _c determines a bijection C(c, Gd)\cong D(Fc, d). Moreover, this bijection is natural in D, since it comes from the natural isomorphism which defines the colimit \eta _c. Thus, this data extends to an adjunction.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor so that, for each object d\in D, there exists a cofree object Gd\in C, i.e. an object Gd\in C together with an isomorphism {D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd)} natural in D. Then there exists a unique extension of this assignment into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C, which is then necessarily right adjoint to F.
Dually, suppose that for each d\in D, there exists a free object Fd\in C. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C which is necessarily left adjoint to F.

An adjunction F\dashv G consists of a pair of opposing functors F: C\leftrightarrows D: G and a natural isomorphism D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition. We say F is left adjoint to G and G is right adjoint to F, and write

When an adjunction is fixed, two maps f\in C and g\in D are adjoint or transposes if they are connected by the adjunction. We sometimes write Fc\xrightarrow {f^\sharp } d and c\xrightarrow {f^\flat } Gd for a pair of adjoint maps.
A colimit of a diagram is a universal cocone.

By the definition of universal elements, a colimit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{colim} D\in C and a cocone D \xrightarrow {\lambda } \operatorname *{colim} D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} D, -)\cong \operatorname *{Cocone}_D.

Let c be an object in a category C, and let J be any category. The constant functor at c is the functor J\xrightarrow {c} C that sends every object of J to c and every morphism of J to the identity 1_c.

The constant functors induce a functor C\xrightarrow {\Delta } J^C to the functor category which sends each object of C to the corresponding constant functor and each morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y to the natural transformation with components \alpha _j = f for each j\in J.
An initial object is a colimit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of colimits, an object i is initial in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism i\to c.
An terminal object is a limit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.

fr:title.text: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements \text {el}(F) has a initial object. Dually, a presheaf C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements has a terminal object.

First let c\in C represent F, so that there is a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\overset {\alpha }{\cong } F. Then the pair (c, \alpha _c(1_c)) is initial in \text {el}(F). Indeed, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), the bijection \alpha _d determines a unique element f\in C(c, d) so that Ff(\alpha _c(1_c)) = y; this exactly expresses initiality.

Conversely, let (c, x) be initial in \text {el}(F). By the Yoneda lemma, the element x\in Fc determines a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\Phi (x)} F; we need to show this is an isomorphism. Initiality of (c, x) asserts that, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), there is a unique map c\xrightarrow {f_y} d such that Ff_y(x) = y. Now in the proof of the Yoneda lemma, \Phi (x) was constructed so that F(\Phi (x)_d)(f) = Ff(x), so the assignment (d, y)\mapsto f_y inverts \Phi (x)_d.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor. The category of elements \text {el}(F) is the comma category *\downarrow F, where *\xrightarrow {*} Set is the inclusion of the point into the singleton set. Explicitly, the category of elements has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, pairs (c, x) where c\in C and x\in Fc;
as morphisms (c, x)\to (d, y), morphisms c\xrightarrow {f} d in C such that Ff(x) = y;
composition and identities inherited from C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The category of elements is further endowed with a forgetful functor \text {el}(F)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C sending (c, x) to c.
Let D\xrightarrow {F} C and E\xrightarrow {G} C be functors. Then the comma category F\downarrow G has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, triples (d\in D, e\in E, Fd\xrightarrow {f} Ge\in C);
composition by gluing along the bottom and top;
identities as in D and E.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A bijection is an isomorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map is bijective if it is both injective and surjective.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A natural isomorphism is an isomorphism in a functor category. Explicitly, it is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.
